0.user_question: Bob is 75 miles ahead of Tom, driving 55 miles per hour. Tom is driving 70 miles per hour. How long will it take Tom to catch up with Bob?

ost_step.1: Since both drivers travel at constant speed on their respective paths towards each other, we can find out when they meet based solely upon relative distances rather than time (which changes over distance). In this case that means dividing instead of subtracting or adding speeds/distances etc... so since Bob starts off 75 mi behind tom then every second as they approach one another bob moves forward 55 miles while toms car advances only half as much because its slower moving due to lower mph but still adds onto his current lead overall which shows us why you need divide here not add like before! We know : Bob begins x=75mi away from home base; Bob drives vb=-55mph toward destination D [note signs used]; meanwhile TOM maintains velocityvt=-(-70)=+70mph , yet gains ground gradually via accelerationgta+(v^2)/(2a) . However our goal isn’t figuring whether BOB wins who gets closer faster first ---our primary task actually involves finding exactly WHEREANDHOWLONGthese two figures intersectsince ONLYTHENwillTOSUCHETEAMUPagainso let s use algebra ! First set d_
ost_step.2: Let $x$ represent the number of hours until Tom catches up to Bob. During these $x$ hours, Bob would cover a distance of $55x$. Similarly, during those same $x$ hours, Tom covers a distance of $70x$. As mentioned earlier, Bob initially has a head start of 75 miles. Therefore, setting up the equation for the scenario yields $$55x = 70x - 75.$$ To solve this linear equation, combine the terms containing variable $x$: $$\begin{align*}55x &= 70x - 75 \\ &\implies \text{substract } 55x\text{:both sides}\\ 0&=15x - 75.\end{align*}$$ Next, isolate variable $x$ through addition properties:$$\begin{align*}0&=\cancelto{}{15}x-75\\ &+\cancelto{}{\boldsymbol{75}}:\\ 0&=15x.\end{align*}$$Finally, multiply both sides of the above resultant equality using inverse property: $$0\times{\frac{1}{15}}=0\cdot{}x,\Rightarrow\quad
ost_step.3: Divide both sides of the resulting equation ($0=15x$) by $15$, thus obtaining $\boxed{x=5}$ as solution. This indicates that within five units of elapsed timespans---in whatever unit specified by problem statement--Tom eventually becomes equal standing once again alongside Bob assuming all variables remain consistent throughout duration considered. direct_answer.text:
We start with calculating how far apart Bob and Tom are getting farther each second using the formula v_relative = |vb| + |vt|. This results in v_relative = 55 + 70 = 125 miles per hour. To calculate the time until Tom meets Bob again, we simply need to determine how long it takes them to cover those initial 75 miles together according to their combined rate. Thus, Time taken would equal Distance divided by Velocity Relative i.e.,  75 / 125 = 0.6 hours ~~ roughly 36 minutes. Hence, It will take approximately around three quarters of an hour for Tom to eventually make contact with Bob once more along their journey.

To put into perspective further simplification if needed consider 'x' representing Total Miles Between Their Starts & Finishes Combined ('x') And Given Information states They Start Out As Follows :     Initial Separation Of Both Vehicles At Dawn Or Some Other Point When Beginning Journey ----Distance From One Another Is Notated With Variable Name 'd'. 0.user_question: Bob is 75 miles ahead of Tom, driving 55 miles per hour. Tom is driving 70 miles per hour. How long will it take Tom to catch up with Bob?

direct_answer.text: To solve this problem we need to first find out how quickly Tom is closing the gap created by their different speeds. That can be determined by subtracting Bob's speed (55 mph) from Tom’s speed (70 mph), which equals 15 mph as the relative rate/speed difference. Next, you divide the initial distance apart (the gap here being 75 miles) by this relative rate. Therefore, 75 divided by 15 results in exactly three hours. It means, tom would require precisely three hours to close the deficit made due to differential travel rates and reach bob’s location if both maintain constant velocities throughout. To summarize; 'time_to_catchup' = InitialGap / RelativeSpeedRate . Substituting known values into equation yields TimeToCatchUp=InitialGap/(SpeedyofTom−Drivenotherspeed). This further simplifies down to Solution(TimeToCatchUp)=75/(70−55)=75/15=5hours hence one could conclude the exact time required based upon calculated figures remains less than anticipated initially presumed i.e., six hours but rather

0.user_question: Bob is 75 miles ahead of Tom, driving 55 miles per hour. Tom is driving 70 miles per hour. How long will it take Tom to catch up with Bob?

1.subquestion: Firstly, calculate the relative speed between Bob and Tom (Tom’s speed minus Bob’s).

subanswer.text: Since Bob drives at 55 mph and Tom drives faster at 70 mph, their relative speed would be 70 - 55 = 15 mph. This indicates that Tom is gaining distance from Bob every hour at this rate. To find out when Tom will overtake Bob completely, you divide the initial lead of Bob by this difference in speeds i.e., Time taken = Distance covered by Bob / Relative Speed = 75miles / 15 mph=  5 hours . Hence, Answer is '5'.

direct_answer.text:
First, let's find out how far apart Bob and Tom are initially:
Initial gap = 75 miles

Now let's consider how fast each driver moves relative to the other. Since Bob drives faster than Tom, eventually Tom will close the initial gap until they meet again. To figure out when that happens, we need to compare their speeds.

Relative speed (how quickly the distance closes between them):
Relative speed = Speed of Tom - Speed of Bob = 70 mph - 55 mph = 15 mph
This means Tom gains ground compared to Bob at a rate of 15 miles every hour.

Next, use this information to compute the amount of time needed for Tom to reduce the original 75-mile difference down to zero using simple division:
Time taken for Tom to reach Bob = Initial Gap / Relative Speed
                          = 75 miles / 15 mph
                          = 5 hours
So, based on calculations provided earlier (hint), indeed it requires precisely halfway around sixty minutes less twenty additional seconds equalizing clockwise circular revolution equivalent round trips conducted jointly before commencing simultaneous reciprocal

0.user_question: Bob is 75 miles ahead of Tom, driving 55 miles per hour. Tom is driving 70 miles per hour. How long will it take Tom to catch up with Bob?

1.subquestion: Firstly, calculate how fast Tom gains distance from Bob every second (or minute).

subanswer.text: First let’s find out what speed difference exists here; tom drives 70 mph while bob drives only 55mph so it means we can say our relative velocity(speed) as v=u+a*t but since no acceleration involved we would consider this formula “relative_velocity = u”. Relative Velocity equation says than when object B moves over another one A speeds up or slow down ,that change doesn’t affect their position relation because if you look through them both . They still moving toward same direction just faster /slower together not against each other..so I believe my question could use term ”absolute” instead ; which was mentioned once earlier : absolute velocities ..now coming back…we know about these constant variables already beforehand right ? well first thing needing attention isn’t time yet !!!because i asked minutes/seconds specifically hence why am using those values below …ok lets plug into above derived eqn again –v=(ua)-vs+(vt)(at)=vu–vs/(ab)+va*(dt)/ta Where V stands vertical axis representing linear distances measured along Xaxis whereas U represents horizontal component accounting motion occurring parallel Zaxis whilst S indicates separation magnitude ranging across Ycomponent accordingly
